LMPD prepares for $68,000 audit triggered by mob violence

Posted: Updated:
By Theo Keith
Email
Connect
tkeith@wave3.com
Cameras were placed on the Big Four Bridge following the mob violence. (Source: WAVE 3 News)

LOUISVILLE, KY (WAVE) – Louisville Metro Police are one step closer to a $68,000 audit to determine how many police officers the city needs to hire.

Concerns about the number of Metro officers sprang up after the mob violence in March, during which about 200 teenagers terrorized parts of downtown by assaulting people and barging into a convenience store.

No audit has answered the question in the merger era, which began in 2003. Louisville has fewer officers per city resident than its nearby peer cities, according to FBI statistics.

[PREVIOUS STORY: LMPD: Mob violence lead to $600,000 in overtime patrols]

The city is likely to hire Alex Weiss Consulting, a well known law enforcement consulting firm based in Illinois, said two Metro Council members who were part of a work group tasked with recommending the auditor.

“They're not going to tell us to revamp the department,” said Kelly Downard, a Republican who represents northeast Jefferson County. “But how many detectives do we need in such-and-such division? Those are the things he's going to come in and tell us to do.”

The March 22 violence triggered several Metro Council committee hearings to address the number of police officers, specifically downtown. Metro Police spent at least $600,000 on police overtime in the three months after the incident.

[PREVIOUS STORY: Metro Council discusses curfews, cameras, community centers following mob violence]

At the time, River City Fraternal Order of Police President Dave Mutchler said the city needed to hire 112 additional officers, a number LMPD Chief Steve Conrad said was unnecessary.

“We've got some people asking for more officers,” Mutchler told council members in April. “We don't even have the officers we should have.”

Mayor Greg Fischer pushed, and the council approved, a new fee on Louisville Gas & Electric's gas customers to pay for 24 more officers than the typical hiring process would allow.

[PREVIOUS STORY: City leaders will investigate response to waterfront attack]

Many of the new officers patrol downtown. The city also opened a Metro Police outpost in the Kentucky International Convention Center and spent $227,000 on new surveillance cameras downtown.

Alex Weiss Consulting should finish a preliminary report by the time council members begin debating the next budget in May, said David James, a Democrat who represents Old Louisville.

Louisville has about 1,250 officers, according to police department figures provided this summer. FBI statistics indicate the city has 18.6 officers per 10,000 residents. By comparison, Indianapolis has 19 officers per 10,000 people, while Nashville has 21.1 and Cincinnati has 33.5.

Metro Police made few arrests after the March violence and four people went free after a grand jury declined to indict them. The case remains open.
